js.core
Class JsGlobal.Number.Member

java.lang.Object
  js.Var.Member<java.lang.Object>
      js.core.JsObject.Member
          js.core.JsClass.Member
              js.core.JsFunction.Member<java.lang.Number>
                  js.core.JsGlobal.Number.Member
Enclosing class:
JsGlobal.Number
public static class JsGlobal.Number.Member
extends JsFunction.Member<java.lang.Number>

An opaque class representing members of its enclosing opaque type.

Note that, this class is opaque but its constructors are all internal. This class and the subclasses of this class are used to declare either opaque public instance fields of the opaque type Var.Member or the opaque public static fields of other opaque types while their constructors are used to define the fields inside opaque classes. Under either circumstance, the field names must be exactly same as the member names, as the opaque fields of opaque types are resolved by re-compilers directly based on the field names.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be created in the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on operations accessing that kind of class objects. Re-compilers must resolve an opaque instance field declared by this class in Var.Member or its subclasses to the JavaScript identifier: 
q.m
where m is the identifier of the field name and q is the identifier resolved from the instance of the enclosing member. Re-compilers must resolve an opaque static field declared by this class in opaque types other than Var.Member and its subclasses to the JavaScript identifier: 
m
where m is the identifier of the field name. And re-compilers must report error on the access to opaque fields declared by this class under any other circumstances.

Field Detail

MAX_VALUE

public final Value.Number.Member MAX_VALUE

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property of this member is the largest number representable in JavaScript. Its value is approximately 1.79E+308.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

MIN_VALUE

public final Value.Number.Member MIN_VALUE

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property of this member is the smallest (closest to zero, not most negative) number representable in JavaScript. Its value is approximately 5E-324.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

NaN

public final Value.Number.Member NaN

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property of this member is a special value that indicates that the result of some mathematical operation (such as taking the square root of a negative number) is not a number. JsGlobal.parseInt and JsGlobal.parseFloat return this value when they cannot parse the specified string, and you might use JsGlobal.Number.NaN in a similar way to indicate an error condition for some function that normally returns a valid number.

JavaScript prints the Number.NaN value as NaN. Note that the NaN value always compares as unequal to any other number, including NaN itself. Thus, you cannot check for the not-a-number value by comparing to Number.NaN; use the JsGlobal.isNaN(Object) function instead. In ECMAScript v1 and later, you can also use the predefined global property NaN instead of Number.NaN.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

NEGATIVE_INFINITY

public final Value.Number.Member NEGATIVE_INFINITY

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property of this member is a special numeric value that is returned when an arithmetic operation or mathematical function generates a negative value greater than the largest representable number in JavaScript (i.e., more negative than -Number.MAX_VALUE).

JavaScript displays the NEGATIVE_INFINITY value as -Infinity. This value behaves mathematically like infinity; for example, anything multiplied by infinity is infinity, and anything divided by infinity is zero. In ECMAScript v1 and later, you can also use -Infinity instead of Number.NEGATIVE_INFINITY.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

POSITIVE_INFINITY

public final Value.Number.Member POSITIVE_INFINITY

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property of this member is a special numeric value returned when an arithmetic operation or mathematical function overflows or generates a value greater than the largest representable number in JavaScript (i.e., greater than Number.MAX_VALUE). Note that when numbers "underflow", or become less than Number.MIN_VALUE, JavaScript converts them to zero.

JavaScript displays the POSITIVE_INFINITY value as Infinity. This value behaves mathematically like infinity; for example, anything multiplied by infinity is infinity, and anything divided by infinity is z ero. In ECMAScript v1 and later, you can also use the predefined global property Infinity instead of Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

prototype

public final JsGlobal.Number.Prototype.Member prototype

An opaque instance field defining a sub-member that is named by the name of this field, qualified by the current member instance of the field, and to access the property of the name on an object.

The prototype property is used when a function is used as a constructor. It refers to an object that serves as the prototype for an entire class of objects. Any object created by the constructor inherits all properties of the object referred to by the prototype property.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this instance field to the identifier of the field name appending to the identifier resolved from its qualifying member with a dot in between.

public JsGlobal.Number with(ObjectLike o)

where m is the identifier name resolved from the current member instance of the invocation.

with

public JsGlobal.Number with()

Evaluates a property, represented by the current member instance, of the JavaScript global object, that is, evaluates the member to a global identifier.
